ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I really enjoy this course material, but would have succeeded more in learning if there had been a bit more structure to the lectures or if we could have had some more discussion-style classes.

Field trips were helpful to be able to see some of the things we discussed in class in person. I wish there was more time for such field trips, though field trips inevitably detract from he amount of class time that can be devoted to other material.

David did not have enough content to use the entire class time. Most of the time, we started the course a half hour to 45min late because time was just wasted on small talk. Usually class ended early because David had to leave to catch his train. I did not feel like I got my money's worth taking this course.

Mr. David Kooris is passionate in teaching. He has very interesting stories to tell and serves as a source of inspiration for us. The materials he teach are interesting but need more organization. His field trips are very useful and provide an eye opening experience for extracurricular learning. Since the class is taught after his regular, very busy work hour, he reasonably can get tired sometimes and, given the lack of student response, he may go on talking about a point for too long so that it lowers students' attention. I suggest that in the future, three changes can be made: 1. Change the seating from rows to circles to stimulate discussion and focus attention (move the tables aside and have only chairs). 2. Encourage weekly presentation of readings in the form of discussion and activity. 3. Modify PowerPoint slides to tie into the readings and to develop presentation script that revolves tightly around the points in the slide so as to minimize tangential information that may reduce student attention and include specific anecdotes to stimulate student interests.
Question 12: This is one of the few courses that deals with transit systems so it would be very valuable for students interested in that realm of sustainability.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: As an undergraduate, it was lovely to have the perspective of a professional in the real world. Often times, I feel the things i learn as an undergrad are fruity and unhelpful or inapplicable to life, but I certainly did not feel that with this course. I also really enjoyed each lecture, the readings and learned a lot!
Discussion and field trips added depth to our conversations.

It was great to learn from David's real-life experiences as a professional in the field. I enjoyed being able to learn concepts as well as hear about his daily life to understand how the field actually operates.
Professor Kooris's experience in the field is fascinating to hear about
Great to learn about planning from a practitioner.
Learning about other students' final paper topics.
Hearing about the challenges of urban planning in the real world. Also, the field trips were great.

I really enjoyed writing the final paper which gave me the freedoms to explore the topic of my interest. I now have a reasonably in depth understanding of my topic. Mr. Kooris has also been very generous in connecting students to his attachs to facilitate their research. I am very happy to have taken his class. It is more than an introduction to a broad range of planning topics; it is a place to be inspired by his stories and him as the example.
The professional insights were very valuable, particularly as a compliment to some of the more theoretical urban courses.

I really enjoyed having lectures with David, it was helpful to have his first-hand insight regarding real-life applications in the planning sector. I liked that the final paper was open-ended and allowed us to explore a topic of our choice.
Lecture and field trips

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: A reduction in readings. Or a brief summary of each reading below in the syllabus so that students can be more selective in which they choose to read.
I think more time could have been spent actually talking about the readings.
The structure of the lectures can be improved by incorporating more diversity in teaching style and in student participation. Similarly, I would have appreciated assignments slightly more rigorous.
I think it would great if part of the class were reserved for discussion of the readings.
The lectures need to be more engaging and fill the entirety of the class. Not end early because there's not enough to talk about.
Perhaps more accessibility of the professor.

The course meandered a lot, which was actually beneficial for those of us who already had a background in urban studies and wanted to think about specific cases; but this might not have been easiest for other students. The assignments weren't the most challenging.
I wish that we had more guest speakers come in to talk to us about different subjects. It would have helped to get a different perspective from other cities/planners.
More homework assignments to reinforce the material from readings and lecture.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I thought that David encouraged everyone to ask questions and participate in lectures. I felt that my fellow students had interesting perspectives that prompted me to think about the class topics in different ways.
The discussions were good but it seemed we would get off topic often.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I've never taken a strict planning class before. Normally land use classes are very locally specific--it was good to see the "regional" picture.
Very helpful! Yale lacks urban planning and urban studies courses.

Very helpful for students interested in planning. There was some overlap with other courses I was taking (Climate Change Mitigation in Urban Areas w/ Karen Seto, Intro to Planning and Development w/ Alex Garvin) but not too much, and the interplay between the courses was valuable.
I am an architecture student, it directly relates to architectural practice.
I was interested in learning about urban planning from an environmental perspective, and I'd say this class helped a lot with forming my understanding.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: As an undergraduate, I have become really interested in becoming an urban planner, so I felt this course could help me see what being a planner actually entails (and it did).
Same as 17.
I wanted to learn about the material and hear the perspective of a practitioner.
To learn more about urban planning and how it works.
For the reason I said above. I am interested in sustainable cities and how planning can create them.
To learn from a professional planner and understand some of the "on-the-ground" challenges the academy can't speak to.
I am interested in urban planning and took this class as an initial foray into the field.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes and no. I wish the course had a real-life, hands on, practical urban planning challenge. But I do feel better able to talk about urban planning in the real world.
I think we could have spent more time talking about readings for some classes.
Learned more about the planning profession and less about actual planning than I expected.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes.
The knowledge and skills did meet my expectations. I felt that I got a fairly comprehensive view of numerous aspects related to urban, suburban, and regional planning.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Choose a paper topic early!

The course material is very interesting, but it is really on you as the student to pay attention during the 3-hour lectures, otherwise you may not come away having learned that much. It's a great experience to learn from a professional in the field though. David's personal anecdotes were very engaging.
This course is better for students who don't have an architectural background. It is less interesting for architecture students.
It is a great course that will teach you a lot about the professional field of urban planning and the politics of urban planning.

Come with specific questions for every class on the topic to fuel the discussion. It's a very interesting class, but it needs to be paired with more practical courses afterwards. Sitting in class for three hours a week absorbing professional knowledge needs to be complimented with design projects that test the theory we learn.
